title: Which party will control the US House of Representatives after the November 2016 election?

I think the likelihood is that Clinton will have mobilised enough of the popular vote to win the presidency but most people will only have voted for her to stop Trump. But I think the Republicans will have put enough focus on winning the House of Representatives.

Most of the ratings changes from Sabato, Cook, etc. over the last two weeks have favored the Democrats, but with less than 2 weeks left none of the raters have close to 30 seats in the lean/tossup range, so it seems pretty unlikely that the Democrats will pick up more than 20 or so seats at best. Generic Congressional ballot polling averages have stayed between +3-5% for Democrats.  Several estimates have projected that they need to have a 6% or larger margin in the House popular vote to gain a majority.

There is an absence of good polling for the House of Representatives. I'm using Presidential polling and making adjustments. Most people, especially these days, vote straight ticket so presidential voles should be a reasonable estimate.  Hillary is polling about 6 points ahead. I estimated gerrymandering based on the 2014 election. In this election, the GOP won 51% of the vote and 57% of the seats, whereas Dems won 45% of the votes and 43% of the seats. This seems like a GOP advantage of 6% I would estimate that contrary to straight ticket voting, there would be some republicans who will vote GOP down ballot but against Trump. I figure 2% adjustment to the GOP. I've noticed a little anti-GOP sentiment among some Trump supporters. I think the actual numbers on this would be low. I put it at 1%. Trump's claim that the election is rigged should depress turnout. I estimate 3%. Hillary had a superior ground game. Normally the two parties both do this and it cancels out. I would estimate this could be 5% at the presidential level, although I don't think it matches up the House of Reps seats, especially because the Dems have not expected to be competitive until later. I put this at 1%. I think Dems have a few low quality candidates in the seat they need to win. This may cost them 1%. Democrats seem to be winning in new voter registrations, although this may not be in the right areas. I put it at 1%. Altogether, this puts Democrats 3% ahead, which is far from the consensus. Perhaps others have seen something I have not. There is also the potential for reactions to Trump's scandals to be delayed and not fully reflected in the polls. The following is an interesting article, but it is only one case, and I can't think of other examples.  http://www.dailykos.com/story/2016/10/20/1582375/-Todd-Akin-shows-how-it-could-get-much-worse-for-Trump-and-cost-Republicans-control-of-Congress
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Helpful: https://www.washingtonpost.com/2016-election-results/house-of-representatives/ For Dems to flip House, they need to defend everything leaning their way, win all 17 toss-up states, and then win 9 of 23 GOP leaning states. That would be straight up impossible if these were all individual races independent of each other. But the results will correlate. If the Dems are having such a good year nationally they start eating into the GOP-leaning districts, then they are likely to take a group of them, not just one or two. Moved my prediction to 23% chance for the Dems, which is close to my prediction of a Clinton 10 point blowout (around 19% right now, though I may increase). I think the Democrats will need to win by around 9 to 12 points nationally to retake the House given the GOP gerrymandering advantage.

I summarized the House race ratings and generic ballot polls in my previous forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/341473 There have been few ratings changes since, but Donald Trump is struggling on the national level and there is some evidence that it may be affecting Republicans in general, as there have been several recent generic ballot polls that have been very favorable for Democrats.  I would expect some of the races to move toward the Democrats in the next few weeks, so I think I was a little too quick to lower the odds of a Democrat takeover so much last week.
D's up 5%. I suppose the "exceptionalism" related to this cycle can't be completely ignored.

I'm raising my estimate of the Democrats' chances to 35% (vs. 15% consensus and 20% prior).   I am struggling a bit  to put my probability estimate here within a coherent framework.  I liked @Marschat 's recent answer on this topic from last week: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/341473 . I think where I differ vs. the 8% probability they came up with is along 3 key dimensions: 1) baseline numbers of generic democratic advantage seem to be moving a bit (+7% this morning in latest WSJ/NBC poll http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/2016_generic_congressional_vote-5279.html).  This is moving into the zone that PEC estimates is needed for democrats to control the house (http://election.princeton.edu/house-polling-margin/).  Obviously 28 days remaining is an eternity, but that's where we are today. 2) Turnout is obviously one of the key questions in determining here. Trump's recent issues in past couple wks (tape, debates, etc), would seem likely to depress turnout.  I can't quantify it (and would welcome opposing views), but it stands to reason that if folks aren't motivated by top of the ticket, they may be less likely to turn out.  3) Ticket-splitting is another key question (will Conservatives who vote Hillary or Johnson support House R's)? I have long thought the answer is probably "Yes," on basis that I think people are usually pretty rational. The last couple days have raised a related and intriguing question though, which is - will hardcore Trump supporters vote for House R's who are not backing him? He seems to be encouraging them not to in his recent tweets: https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/785854588654092290 . This article sums up status quo before these tweets, including some references that private polling of house GOP members have started seeing some drop-off in down-ticket support: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/donald-trump-campaign-republicans-229577.  For record, at least ~32 House members are actively not supporting trump, and that doesn't include Paul Ryan who said yesterday morning he won't campaign w/ him and won't defend him (https://twitter.com/Taniel/status/785161346409259008).   So, where does that leave us?  
a) Republicans have a pretty large built-in buffer here and for all the reasons/sources @marschat lays out, it's reasonable to think most likely they will keep the house. 
b) That said, polls are moving in the wrong direction, and at least at nat'l level they seem to be within zone where D's have a shot.
c) We seem to be witnessing a bit of a civil war w/in R party that raises more questions than usual around turn-out and whether or not Trump supporters would support 'disloyal' House R's (and vice versa).   Through that combo, I'm moving it from my prior of ~20% to 35% (half of the way to a 50-50 coin flip). I still think R's most likely keep the house but am more unsure every day.

I've been following house race ratings and generic congressional ballot poll questions. Averaging the ratings from each of these sources has the democrats gaining about 10 seats.
Larry Sabato: http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2016-house/
Cook Political Report: http://cookpolitical.com/house/charts/race-ratings
Rothenberg & Gonzales: http://rothenberggonzales.com/ratings/house
Daily Kos: http://www.dailykos.com/pages/election-outlook/2016-race-ratings#house The generic ballot question has the democrats with around a 3-5% advantage, depending on how and which polls are aggregated:
RCP: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/2016_generic_congressional_vote-5279.html
PEC: http://election.princeton.edu/house-polling-margin/
HuffPo: http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-national-house-race
538: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/senate/generic-ballot/ Sam Wang at PEC has made a new estimate for how much the Democrats need to win the House popular vote by in order to control the chamber.  His estimate is that they'll need at least a 6% margin due to gerrymandering and geographic clustering of Democrats in urban areas.  This is a surprisingly large margin, but the last few elections have been trending in that direction, so it may be correct, and the polls don't have the Democrats quite reaching that number. In addition, I think we're at the point in the election where the House race ratings are going to be pretty accurate.  However, you only have to go back to 2010 election to find an election where the ratings were significantly off in one direction ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2010#Predictions ).  The Republicans gained about 10 more seats than the average of the ratings suggested they would, including some misses in some districts that were expected to be pretty favorable to Democrats.  There are just enough competitive races this year where a miss this big could occur, but it still seems pretty unlikely to reach the level where the Democrats would take control.

I'm switching my probability estimate from a Dem win to a Repub win of the House.

Some updates from an article in today's NYT: "What are the chances that Democrats retake the House?"  (reading from printed paper, do not have link) This hasn't changed: Democrats will need to pick up 30 seats and as of today, it's hard to identify 30 seats where Republicans are in serious danger. But, if Hillary were to maintain her present lead up til November, "some of the conditions for big democratic gains might start to emerge, and 2016 could turn into a so-called wave election" (when one party makes big gains across the nation and across the board in the Senate, House, state governments and the presidency).  The article notes that, typically, most of the big waves tend to come at the expense of the president's party, when presidential approval rating is below 50% and they are more likely during midterm elections.  In terms of the effect of Hillary's significant lead over Trump, the article notes that Nixon's huge victory in 1972 didn't give Republicans the House.  Neither Reagan's, nor Bush I or Bill Clinton.  Gains in all those were modest.   Yet, the article says, if Hillary won by 7-8 points, there is a chance the Democrats will retake the House because the relationship between presidential and down-ballot vote is showing to be tightening.  The article also notes that so far, Trump doesn't seem to have done enough damage to the rest of the party to put the House in question.  The Cook Political Report estimated that 36 Republican seats are either toss ups or leaning Republican.  Many GOP voters with reservations about Trump are sticking by their party.   Well-educated white voters, says the article, are supporting Hillary by 12 points, but, among them, the House Republicans still have the edge.   The article wraps up saying that the GOP may control the House for at least a decade.  "The structural advantages underpinning it are strong. The greater the odds of Hillary winning the more likely it is that at Republican House will strengthen.

The Democrat's magic number is 30 seats.  I'm looking at house race ratings and the generic congressional ballot poll question Ratings of house races suggest Democrats can expect to pick up 10-15 seats, maybe 20 if they exceed expectations
Larry Sabato: http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2016-house/
Cook Political Report: http://cookpolitical.com/house/charts/race-ratings
Rothenberg & Gonzales: http://rothenberggonzales.com/ratings/house In generical congressional ballot polling RCP currently has D+3%: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/2016_generic_congressional_vote-5279.html
PEC uses the HuffPo Pollster feed which follows a different set of tracking polls and has D+8%: http://election.princeton.edu/house-polling-margin/

The RCP average on the date of the election has historically been off the actual popular vote by 1-3% (in 2014 it was off by 3.3% in favor of the democrats): http://www.dailykos.com/story/2014/11/3/1340632/-The-generic-congressional-ballot-the-US-House-popular-vote-and-democratic-legitimacy Comments:

There is a lot of time, many districts still haven't had primaries.  I would guess that the polling average will be more volatile, but I wouldn't ignore it and if it continues to show a sizable lead for the Democrats near the election I would increase the odds for the Democrats.  I would also note that most ratings changes thus far have moved races toward the democrats, so it is possible that the raters are still underestimating the Dems chances.

This is becoming a really interesting problem -- Democrats are ahead in the generic House polling by about 7 points, which should make them more likely than not to take back control, according to Sam Wang's polling chart. And yet, a 30 seat deficit is a large undertaking and the qualitative prognosticators are bearish that they can take it back. Rothenberg and Gonzales think 219 seats are safe for Republicans, essentially giving the Democrats close to a 0% chance of taking the House. Cook Political has 202 solid seats for Republicans with another 23 as lean/likely for them -- more uncertainty but still very favorable to Republicans. Given that most of the polling on the House has been with registered voters, which typically overrate Democrats' standing (thanks Nate Silver), I think the markets probably have this aggregated well at the moment. PredictWise shows an 82% chance that the Republicans keep the House. Still, I'd buy at that price. I think the GOP is very likely to keep the House. I have them at 90%.
Even if the Democrats win every district that Obama won in the 2012 election, they would still need more. The odds are definitely stacked against them.
Would require the Democrats to win 30 seats net.

http://www.truthdig.com/report/item/grass-roots_group_launches_plan_to_take_20160706 "The vision sounds grand but not implausible: Hillary Clinton commands a large voter turnout in November, while Republicans, wary of Donald Trump, shun the polls. The uneven turnout results in a big Clinton win, with down-ballot voting that also secures the Senate for Democrats. A strategic targeting of congressional races by an emboldened populace wins the House, sealing Democratic control of the White House, the Senate and the House of Representatives. "So goes the pitch of attorney Stephen Schear and filmmaker Theo Schear, who just launched letstakethehouse.org in a bid to take on the toughest piece of the triumvirate puzzle: the House of Representatives.
. . . 
"Their group has identified 37 races nationwide that Democrats have a fighting chance to win if they can match or exceed the funding of their Republican rivals. Democratic fundraising deficits range from $60,000 to $1.9 million in the races identified. Thirty wins would take back the House, assuming Democrats hold their current seats. "Schear joked that the project’s goal to raise $20 million might seem daunting to the group of 20 or so activists that showed up for the first party, a group well below the 1 percent. But the record of people power harnessed by the Bernie Sanders campaign, which raised over $220 million, indicates that small-donation funding of $20 million spread across 37 races (approximately $540,000 each) is possible, if a public already energized by Sanders’ populist appeal buys into the idea.
. . . 
"The activists’ targeting strategy takes a page from the Republican super PAC playbook, which makes a practice of targeting vulnerable seats. One of the “Let’s Take the House” candidates, Colleen Deacon, is vying to retake New York’s 24th congressional seat (Syracuse) from Republican John Katko, who benefited from Republican super PAC targeting in the midterm election. New York 2014, a super PAC funded almost exclusively by five millionaires and billionaires, bought Katko a 10-day media blitz in 2014 that secured the seat in a district that had gone solidly for Obama—with double-digit leads—in both the 2008 and 2012 elections. "While the pro-Obama demographics of the 24th district indicate that Deacon could win back the seat, Katko has $1 million more in the bank in the crucial early days of the campaign. “Let’s Take the House” activists see this as a winnable race if the playing field can be leveled. There are seats like that all over the country, they say, in which Republicans have the advantage only because they have the money. So Schear and friends are raising the call for party time. “If we can raise enough money to counter the Republicans’ current fundraising edge in swing House races, we can party ourselves into power,” he said.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This organization is predicated on the belief stated in the last sentence:  that money wins elections.   How valid is that belief?

At least 3 factors make Dem control extremely unlikely.  1) Republicans have their largest House majority (+59 seats) since 1928, so the "margin of safety" for Republican control is very large.  2) Democrats are more concentrated in urban areas than they've ever been before, creating a natural geographic impediment for Democrats to pick up seats.  3) District gerrymandering following the massive Republican wins in state legislatures in 2010 have created even larger structural advantages for Republicans seeking House seats. The only reason this forecast isn't >95% Republican probability of control is that there is a non-zero chance that their presidential nominee dramatically underperforms and causes large down ballot problems for Republicans.

Add in Voter ID laws in states where Sec. Clinton might otherwise be able to flip a House seat or two, and you're looking at a majority that may be smaller, but won't be toppled. This election is about fear, not about hope. Younger voters-- who could sweep in a new majority if present in number-- are not motivated by fear. Older voters-- who will be voting in number-- are.

It's unlikely that the Ds will take back the House, but the question, of course, is how unlikely? Here's a stab at answering that question. First, the basics: There are 435 Congressional seats with voting rights, though 1 of these seats is currently empty. There are also 6 seats (from the U.S. territories, commonwealths, and the District of Columbia) without voting rights. Since the question is about control over the House, I'll ignore the seats without voting rights. (Sorry, folks. You really should have voting rights, but I can't fix that here.) So, in lieu of further vacancies, a party needs at least 218 seats to control the House. (I ignore here the complications raised by the election of third-party candidates, as this is unlikely to be relevant in 2016.) At the moment, the Rs have 246 seats, and the Ds have 188. So the Ds would have to win a net of 30 seats from the Rs to gain control of the House.  That's a lot of seats! But it's not like we've never seen such a thing. As recently as 2010, Rs picked up 63 seats in a single election cycle. A smart thing to do would be to look through all of the recent elections, and see what the average amount of change has been. But I've been struggling to find these data in a digestible form[1]. I ended up working with a data set that had the virtue of going back to the beginning of our Republic but which also had a number of annoying typos in it[2], which I think I've managed to correct. I limited my number crunching to all of the elections following 1921, the first year in which the number of Congressional Representatives was fixed at 435. In the average House election (whatever that means), Ds lose 2 seats, and Rs pick up 2.33. Why aren't these numbers symmetrical, you ask? Third-party candidates. More importantly, there's is a ton of variance. The standard deviation for the Ds is 36.23 and for the R is 37.07. On no less than 18 occasions (out of 51 possibilities), one party picked up at least 30 seats.  1914 election: R Pres (Taft) in office during election, Rs pick up 66 seats
1920 election: D Pres (Wilson) in office during election, Ds lose 59 seats
1922 election: R Pres (Harding) in office during election, Rs lose 75 seats
1928 election: R Pres (Harding) in office during election, Rs pick up 30 seats
1930 election: R Pres (Hoover) in office during election, Rs lose 53 seats
1932 election: R Pres (Hoover) in office during election, Rs lose 101 seats
1938 election: D Pres (Roosevelt) in office during election, Ds lose 71 seats
1942 election: D Pres (Roosevelt) in office during election, Ds lose 45 seats
1946 election: D Pres (Truman) in office during election, Ds lose 55 seats
1948 election: D Pres (Truman) in office during election, Ds pick up 75 seats
1958 election: R Pres (Ike) in office during election, Rs lose 48 seats
1964 election: D Pres (LBJ) in office during election, Ds pick up 36 seats
1966 election: D Pres (LBJ) in office during election, Ds lose 47 seats
1974 election: R Pres (Ford) in office during election, Rs lose 48 seats
1980 election: D Pres (Carter) in office during election, Ds lose 36 seats
1994 election: D Pres (Clinton) in office during election, Ds lose 54 seats
2006 election: R Pres (Bush II) in office during election, Rs lose 33 seats
2010 election: D Pres (Obama) in office during election, Ds lose 63 seats Bad news for the Ds: The majority (78%) of the time, the party that loses 30 or more seats in the House is the party with the sitting president at the time of the election. Worse news for Ds: The party with a sitting president loses on average 13.3 seats per House election. Slightly better news for the Ds: Given the high level of variance, there is a 0.123 probability of picking up 30 or more seats if your party holds the White House. (I haven't shown my work here because it was tedious to do and, I reckon, would be even more so to look at.) So far, so good. But foxes are supposed to have more than one trick up their furry little sleeves. So let's try it from another angle. According to the Cook Political Report, there are 65 district races that are to at least some degree competitive[3]. 19 of these are currently held by Ds, and the remaining 46 are held by Rs. That leaves 169 safe seats for the Ds and 200 safe seats for the Rs. The question, then, is this: How likely is it that the Ds can win 49 of the 65 (or more) of the competitive seat?[4] Glad you asked. CPR ranks these races as Solid R, Likely R, Leans R, Tossup, Leans D, Likely D, and Solid D. On the basis of CPR's own assessment of their levels of accuracy[5] and a little bit of body English, I'm translating these qualitative judgments into quantitative judgments as follows: Solid R: 0.997 probability of an R victory, 0.003 probability of a D victory
Likely R: 0.95 probability of an R victory, 0.05 probability of a D victory
Leans R: 0.85 probability of an R victory, 0.15 probability of a D victory
Tossup: 0.50 probability of an R victory, 0.50 probability of a D victory
Leans D: 0.15 probability of an R victory, 0.85 probability of a D victory
Likely D: 0.05 probability of an R victory, 0.95 probability of a D victory
Solid D: 0.003 probability of an R victory, 0.997 probability of a D victory The average expected outcome is that Ds win 29 (rounding up from 28.79) of the 65 contested seats. That gets them to 197 total seats in the House, a nice outcome with their party holding the White House but far short of a majority. I ran a 1,000 round Monte Carlo simulation, and not once did Ds win more than 40 of these 65 seats (though they did hit 39 on a few occasions). Since Ds need to win 49 of the 65 competitive seats to take control of the House, I'm pretty damn pessimistic about their chances.  "Unless...unless it's 1964 all over again," you might say. As we saw above, in 1964 LBJ ran as an unelected incumbent against an extremely unpopular R candidate, Barry Goldwater, who won the nomination after a highly contentious convention. Sound familiar? LBJ won the presidency in a landslide, and the Ds netted themselves 36 seats, 6 more than they need in 2016[6]. But I'd urge caution about betting the farm on another 1964. Marx's line about history repeating itself "the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce" has to be taken with a grain of salt. He was, after all, referring to "all great world-historic facts and personages"[7]. Honestly I don't think either Barry Goldwater or Donald Trump count as great world-historic personages, and I don't their runs for office are great world-historic facts. And Marx was at a point in his career where the pithy phrase was sometimes more important than the carefully reasoned analysis. Anyway, it's unwise to become fixated on a single data point when so much data is available. In 2003, we were obsessed with Munich, and anyone who voiced doubts about going to war with Iraq was an Attlee-esque appeaser, never mind the many, many dis-analogies. Sure, Mr. Trump could bomb as a general election candidate and drag down a lot of R House Representatives with him; I don't deny that for a second. But Rs running for House seats have been running away from Mr. Trump for some time now[8], and there are reports that the Koch brothers are shifting their considerable financial resources away from the presidential race (where they don't like what's on the menu) to Congressional and state-level races[9] where money makes a bigger difference. If we can see the risk to Rs in the House, it's no surprise that they can too and that they're acting tactically to try to counter the risk.  TL;DR: The historical data suggests something like a 12% chance that the Ds will retake the House, while the race-by-race data suggests a lot less, probably less than 1%. I'll blend these odds a nock it up 3% because treating the House races as if they were independent from one another (or, more properly, as if they were independent of common factors like who's at the top of the ticket) is obviously inadequate. COMMENT:  The financial picture for the RNC seems to suggest that there will be significantly less support for House races than in the past, both because of decreased support for state party operations and because it sounds like the focus is going to be on retaining the Senate.   This suggests 2 things to me:  1) the RNC considers keeping control of the House reasonably likely, and 2) a few weak GOP House candidates may be considered somewhat expendable by the GOP, and therefore more vulnerable. So, for purposes of this forecast, I'm thinking that the GOP will retain control of the House, but with a smaller margin.

Baseline: only 3 out of 17 presidential election years (http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/Research/Files/Reports/2013/07/vital-statistics-congress-mann-ornstein/Vital-Statistics-Chapter-2--Congressional-Elections.pdf?la=en) have seen a swing in house of more than 30 seats (the number needed for Democrats to hit 218): 18% (low baseline, but given the last time it happened was in 1980 when Reagan beat Carter, one could easily argue the baseline should be even lower).

Currently Democrats have 188, Republicans 213, so there has to be a net swing of 30 seats to the Democrats for them to take control. The last time the Dems gained 30 was in 2006. Since then the only other swing of that magnitude or greater was in 2010, when the Republicans gained 63. From the Cook Political Report of 18 March http://cookpolitical.com/house/charts/race-ratings
205 R and 174 D seats are "solid", leaving 56 competitive seats. Of these, Cook considers 14 R and 3 D as "toss-ups", which could go either way. Splitting them equally would give the Dems a gain of 6-8 seats. They would thus need 22-24 of the remaining 39 seats, but Cook has just 9 "likely Democrat" and 5 "lean Democrat".  In the extreme case of the Democrats winning all the tossups being defended by Republicans they would gain only 18 seats overall, and would need to win all of the 13 "lean Republican" seats to gain 31.  There's a similar analysis by Rothenberg and Gonzales on 25 March.  http://rothenberggonzales.com/ratings/house
They say Dems have 183 safe seats compared to 218 for the Republicans, with just 34 seats in play, 27 of which are Republican. Further, of those 34, they consider 7 as Republican favored" so the Democrats are unlikely to win 30. (Thanks to @Jean-Pierre for pointing me to the two references I've used above). Even though there could be a Democratic landslide at the Presidential level, in which case the Senate could change hands too, the House seems likely to remain Republican because of the way district boundaries have been drawn by mostly Republican state legislatures.  In addition, there's an interesting article suggesting a long term shift from Democrats to Republicans in areas where "fracking" and shale oil have improved local economies. http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/the-surprising-link-between-fracking-and-republican-power-in-congress/?utm
If that's the case, then the Democrats may find it difficult to reverse many of the Republican gains made in recent election cycles, as some hitherto "purple" states are trending further to "red".

I need to think more about this, but I would like to make one point now that I've been thinking a lot about:  Is the conventional wisdom regarding the down-ballot effects of a Trump ticket correct? Conventional wisdom (and many comments) seem to assume there is some chance (even a high chance), that having Trump on the top of the ticket will suppress support for R senate & house candidates.  Although clearly possible, this strikes me as quite unlikely.  Down-ballot effects (as I understand them), are driven by low turn-out, caused by voter apathy / weak appeal for top-of-ticket.  If the #nevertrump folks stay home (i.e. the R's & I's who say they won't vote for him), then I would grant that that's bad for the Republicans across the ticket.  I also would grant that past precedent provides some evidence to suggest this is often the case when you have a President that lacks appeal with important parts of the base. This is a unusual year though, and it appears to me that most people seem quite invested in and motivated by the political process and potential outcomes here (both Trump supporters and the #nevertrump crowd).  I wouldn't be that surprised if there are reasonable %'s of moderate republicans and/or independents who cannot come around to Trump and who either vote for Hillary or a 3rd party, while still supporting down-ballot republican senators and representatives.  I also wouldn't be that surprised if ultimately a good chunk of "traditional" republicans who currently say they can't support him ultimately do vote for Trump.  What I WOULD be very surprised by is low turn-out amongst republicans and conservative-leaning independents this year.  I would also be VERY surprised if all the #neverTrump voters who are currently supporting Kasich/Rubio/Cruz/etc and say they would vote for Hillary vs. Trump somehow also find it in their hearts to also support Democratic congressmen.  Denying Trump is one thing, changing your political views is another. It's way to early to have a clear view on individual races here, but I think it's reasonably clear we're going to have a hard fought (very nasty) fight for President with huge stakes for the direction of the country.  I would guess most voters will strongly dislike both Trump and Hillary by the time we get to November (and maybe a 3rd party candidate too if anyone else runs).  That said, I don't see anything to suggest apathy or low turnout, and I don't sense a mood in the electorate that is swinging to Democrats (swinging populist, sure), so I'm not so sure we can so easily translate discord about the top of the ticket on the R side into poor chances for the down-ticket.  Trump will almost certainly win nomination, and he will also almost certainly bring in many new R voters.  He might not keep many of the current R voters, but my money is on most of those folks still voting for someone and also largely remaining conservative in their choices.

- Incumbents seeking a Senate Seat leaving their House seat for grabs:  7 Democrats, 5 Republicans

There are some 11 other "somewhat competitive" races in which 3 are leaning Democrat, 8 are leaning Republican. Most House seats are "safe seats" for one party or the other.  If you look at individual districts, you can see how this works.  Members of Congress are rated on their votes by numerous special interest groups.  It turns out that you can't get elected to the House in very many places by taking a middle road.  You have to line up on one end of the political spectrum, or the other.  You need to have high ratings from the watchdog groups that focus on issues that are important in your district.  State Legislatures have supported this game by gerrymandering most of the districts in the country.  This makes things convenient for fund raising and vote getting.  Senators run state-wide, but House members run district-by-district,  Sure, trouble in the Presidential race can have an impact down ballot.  But if you vote in a typical House district, it would be very difficult for you to give up on every special interest issue that has been near and dear to your heart.  Chances are, your representative has earned top roll call scores from all of your favorite special interest groups.  He or she has been proven to vote the way you think.  You're not going to vote for someone else.  This is what makes it so difficult to shift a majority in the House.

There's not a good way to quantify this without doing a lot more state-by-state research, so I guess I mostly just looked at how often a margin like this has been overcome before (twice in the last 20 congresses, 112th and 104th), both of them from Democratic to Republican. Dem takeovers have seemed more gradual? But with a somewhat confused Republican identity right now, the odds might bump a bit higher than one in ten. At least that's what I think so far, without diving too deeply into it.

The holders of House seats are overwhelmingly determined by state houses, during redistricting. Republicans were in a particularly good position to claim/protect those seats after the 2010 census, as they held majorities in more state legislatures than the Democrats did. Roll Call's 2016 election map (http://media.cq.com/raceratings/) shows 219 of 247 current Republican seats as "safe," with 7 "leaning," 5 "favored" and 3 "tilting." Only 11 are "toss-ups." The safe seats, alone, ensure the majority. And their holders will, without question, all be campaigning against the Democratic presidential nominee (which contender makes little difference), who will "fire up the base" much more thoroughly than even Donald Trump is likely to do for the Democrats. This may not work in the Senate, but that house is beyond the scope of this question.
